data.title: Piano coloring
data.statement:
Given [[N]] keys on the piano, determine if they are {{black}} or {{white}}.

Piano keyboard looks like this (there are more octaves on the right and left):
` __ ____  ____ ___ __ ____  ____  ____ ___ __ ____  ____ ___ __ ____  ____  ____ ___ 
|  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |
|  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |
|  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |
|  | C# || D# |   |  | F# || G# || A# |   |  | C# || D# |   |  | F# || G# || A# |   |
|  | Db || Eb |   |  | Gb || Ab || Bb |   |  | Db || Eb |   |  | Gb || Ab || Bb |   | . . .
|  |____||____|   |  |____||____||____|   |  |____||____|   |  |____||____||____|   |
|     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |
|     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |
|  C  |  D  |  E  |  F  |  G  |  A  |  B  |  C  |  D  |  E  |  F  |  G  |  A  |  B  |
|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|

^ first octave                            ^ another octave`

Each octave has {{12}} keys, {{7}} of them are white and {{5}} of them are black.

A <<semitone>> is a distance between two closest notes, such as {{E}} to {{F}}; {{F}} to {{F#}} and {{E}} to {{Eb}}.

Each key is represented by an uppercase letter from {{A}} to {{G}} possibly followed by an <<accidental>>.
- sharp {{#}} raises the pitch of a note by {{1}} semitone;
- flat {{b}} lowers the pitch of a note by {{1}} semitone;
- double sharp {{x}} raises the pitch of a note by {{2}} semitones;
- double flat {{bb}} lowers the pitch of a note by {{2}} semitones.

<<Note that for example>>:
- {{B#}} is the same note as {{C}};
- {{Cx}} is the same note as {{D}};
- {{Cb}} is the same note as {{B}};
- {{Dbb}} is the same note as {{C}}.

data.stubGenerator:
read n:int
loop n read key:word(3)

loop n write black/white
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[N]] for the number of keys.
<<Next [[N]] lines:>> A string representing a key.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given N keys on the piano, determine if they are black or white.

Piano keyboard looks like this (there are more octaves on the right and left):
 __ ____  ____ ___ __ ____  ____  ____ ___ __ ____  ____ ___ __ ____  ____  ____ ___ 
|  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |
|  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |
|  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |  |====||====|   |  |====||====||====|   |
|  | C# || D# |   |  | F# || G# || A# |   |  | C# || D# |   |  | F# || G# || A# |   |
|  | Db || Eb |   |  | Gb || Ab || Bb |   |  | Db || Eb |   |  | Gb || Ab || Bb |   | . . .
|  |____||____|   |  |____||____||____|   |  |____||____|   |  |____||____||____|   |
|     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |
|     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |     |
|  C  |  D  |  E  |  F  |  G  |  A  |  B  |  C  |  D  |  E  |  F  |  G  |  A  |  B  |
|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|_____|

^ first octave                            ^ another octave


Each octave has 12 keys, 7 of them are white and 5 of them are black.

A semitone is a distance between two closest notes, such as E to F; F to F# and E to Eb.

Each key is represented by an uppercase letter from A to G possibly followed by an accidental.
- sharp # raises the pitch of a note by 1 semitone;
- flat b lowers the pitch of a note by 1 semitone;
- double sharp x raises the pitch of a note by 2 semitones;
- double flat bb lowers the pitch of a note by 2 semitones.

Note that for example:
- B# is the same note as C;
- Cx is the same note as D;
- Cb is the same note as B;
- Dbb is the same note as C.
Input
Line 1: An integer N for the number of keys.
Next N lines: A string representing a key.
Output
N lines: white or black
Constraints
1 ≤ N ≤ 100
Example
Input
3
C#
E
Ab
Output
black
white
black
